sen.e: Hatsu-uma is a Inari-sha shrines fair (ennichi), often counted as one of the specific days for seasons other than the twenty-four divisions of a year.

A Hatsu-uma festival is held at Inari-sha shrines, and this is often counted as one of Japan's zassetsu (festivals other than those held on the twenty-four points of the old solar calendar, the five seasonal festivals, etc.).

sen.j: 全国で稲荷神の本社である京都の伏見稲荷神社の神が降りた日が和銅4年のこの日であったとされている。
sen.e: Throughout Japan, it is believed that the deity of Fushimi Inari-jinja shrine in Kyoto, the headquarters of the Inari-sha shrines, descended on this day in 711.

sen.e: Hatsu-uma was originally observed on the first horse day in February on the old lunisolar calendar; though, now it is observed on the first horse day in February on the new calendar.

sen.e: Besides, although the festival was held on the first day of horse after the beginning of spring (the first day of spring according to the lunar calendar) in ancient times, it is now generally accepted that the festival is held on the first day of horse in February.
